ryzymF42OGcuGmS2q8sw4.title: A step by step guide to build a Gatsbyjs blog

c3jyz8EzE1W4gkmEw0gaQSgdescriptionTextNo.description:
Wordpress is great. But wait ...there is something better.
Imagine a platform, which gives complete independence to your team of writers, photographers, developers, editors!

internal.content:
Wordpress is great. But wait ...there is something better.
Imagine a platform, which gives complete independence to your team of writers, photographers, developers, editors!

c3jyz8EzE1W4gkmEw0gaQSgblogTextNode.blog:
<p/>
<p/>
Wordpress is great. But wait ...there is something better.

Imagine a platform, which gives complete independence to your team of writers, photographers, developers, editors! 

The photographers upload the media, the writers use the media and write up the articles. The editors review and publish the articles. The developers simultaneously roll out a new version of the platform.

Now this is possible. 

[Contentful](https://contentful.com) + [Netlify](https://www.netlify.com) + [Tech](https://www.gatsbyjs.org) (Gatsby, Hugo etc) 

Using Contently, your writers, photographers and editors semalessly collaborate.

Your development team rolls out new version in the tech of their choice. Netlify brings the two together and publishes the site as soon as anyone makes an update.

This gives you unmatched performance, security and scalability of static sites with no infrastructure costs. Beautiful. It cannot get better. Really. This architecture is also called the [Jamstack](https://jamstack.org/)

This blog is a very simple example of this arhitecture.

c1J5yJZB0GIY8EMWiOaKaCGdescriptionTextNo.description: Optimising the sizes of your images gives your users a much better user experience. Here I share some useful tips on how to go about doing this. Also links on how facebook and medium have optimised their image loading for a better user experience.

internal.content: Optimising the sizes of your images gives your users a much better user experience. Here I share some useful tips on how to go about doing this. Also links on how facebook and medium have optimised their image loading for a better user experience.

c1J5yJZB0GIY8EMWiOaKaCGblogTextNode.blog:
When we are building tech from scratch we go to work on some mundane but important things which may not be core to our product.

Using an existing CMS system or an existing framework or a site generator makes a lot of things easy as they come built in with whats needed and hence we do not have to re-invent the wheel.

But sometimes, when we are building something unique grounds up, we got to reinvent the wheel, but it is much easier now, as the smart folks have already figured it out and it is about understanding whats already figured out.

One of these things is resizing images to make them responsive. 

Optimising the sizes and resolutions of our images gives our users a much better user experience. User experience is a loaded term and I will not get into that here. But rather will outline a few things about resizing images and making them responsive.

There are typically two dominant use cases. The first one is when the image width is dependent on the screen width and the second one is when the image width is fixed, that is it will have the same width across all devices say - 300px on all screen widths.

In both these cases, we will need to resize the images so it is optimised for multiple screen dimensions and __screen resolutions__ (E.g Retina displays).

Typically it suffices to create images with widths close to 

__1. 200px
2. 400px
3. 800px
4. 1600px
5. 2400px__

If the image height is not fixed, then the image is resized maintaining the aspect ratio of the image.

If the image height needs to be a factor of the width, then when the image is resized it is also cropped.

The entire process of resizing the images to the appropriate sizes and cropping can be automated.

I had hacked together such a piece, which created responsive images for me on the cloud. I used AWS Lambda to resize and crop the images. On Lambda imagmagick and sharp were the two options I had. I went with sharp as it was faster for the resizing use case.

For the responsive code, I referred to the gatsby image plugin. The code is open sourced. The [gatsby image plugin](https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby/tree/master/packages/gatsby-plugin-sharp) provides an easy interface to have responsive images on gatsby sites.

The Img tag, instead of `src`, takes either `sizes` or `resolutions` as its props. The sizes is an object with srcset, src and sizes. 
 (..and more):
 
 ```graphql
 "sizes": {
        "srcSet": "/static/rishikund-62f05.jpg 200w,\n/static/rishikund sajdhar-dc2b4.jpg 400w,\n/static/rishikund-381d6.jpg 800w,\n/static/rishikund-14504.jpg 1024w",
        "sizes": "(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px",
        "src": "/static/rishikund sajdhar pic-e7e21d0046509e1f847cfef167ba624f-381d6.jpg"
      }
```

The resolutions is an object with srcSet along with the resolutions like 1x, 1.5x etc, src, width (..and more)

```graphql
"resolutions": {
        "srcSet": "/static/rishikund-47df3.jpg 1x,\n/static/rishikund-9f62f.jpg 1.5x,\n/static/rishikund-34191.jpg 2x",
        "src": "/static/rishikund-47df3.jpg",
        "width": 400,
        "height": 266.796875,
        "aspectRatio": 1.499267935578331
      }
```

The gatsby image plugin uses the sharp library to create the image assests needed! It has a lot more going within it, in terms of making the image loading smooth. 

Gatsby itself, uses GraphQL to fetch the images to hydrate the react components. The GraphQL query to fetch a responsive image of a fixed width and height would be like the following:



Here are a few good links which helped me better my understanding of responsive images and image loading.

[Good website to learn about responsive images](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Multimedia_and_embedding/Responsive_images)

[Responsive images, a very nice multi part series blog.](https://cloudfour.com/thinks/responsive-images-101-definitions/)

[This is a pretty long read. Use cases for loading images](http://usecases.responsiveimages.org/)

Below are the next steps, once you have resized your images.

[This Facebook article is 💯 They are powering this system through GraphQL 🔥](https://code.facebook.com/posts/991252547593574/the-technology-behind-preview-photos/)

[How medium does progressive image loading](https://jmperezperez.com/medium-image-progressive-loading-placeholder/)

[The blur up technique for loading background images](https://css-tricks.com/the-blur-up-technique-for-loading-background-images/)

In an upcoming blog, I will share how to resize the image using lambda and sharp with the code I used.

c6wo4Wf9gbe6cK2Q66oo2MYdescriptionTextNo.description: Could templates of technology along with micro services cause the next round of disruption? The current set of start ups are templating technology with micro services!

internal.content: Could templates of technology along with micro services cause the next round of disruption? The current set of start ups are templating technology with micro services!

c6wo4Wf9gbe6cK2Q66oo2MYblogTextNode.blog:
In the current age of virality, there is a lot of noise, but disruptions happen silently and it may be happening while we speak.

I think AI, VR, AR, IOT are enablers. (I intentionally left out blockchain as I feel it is still in early days)

I believe there are a few silent trends which could be big while being beneficial to the masses. 

I give below a mix of human needs and some upcoming tech capabilites nicely mixed up. So you could join the dots yourself :)

1. __Personalisation__: In the age of technology and bots. There is an even greater need for personalisation. There is also a basic human nature to want to stand out from the rest. Services like facebook do not help in this as all are created equal. __Now think of templates. What if everthing technology was a template.__ 

2. __Templating the web__ : Wordpress made popular the concept of themes. Now we have technologies which is destructuring the web, so it can be more easily constructed. For example, ReactJs. ReactJs is a library which allows developers to create reusable templates for websites and apps. Using this library, it is possible to __build websites from data.__ (This particular website is built using GatsbyJs, a static website generator built in react.). __Now think microservices.
__

3. __Microservices or Serverless:__ __This is a template too.__ Not tied by the browser or anything. A template of your business(logic). Computing has become very cheap, thanks to serverless technologies like AWS Lambda. This will reduce costs tremendously and in many cases will make services free. 

4. __AI__: But AI needs data. How to get data? Think microservices. 

5. __Everything is online__: It is an online world now. *But it is aggregated.* They cannot stand out. Think templates for personalisation.

Now think, if it was possible for anyone to create a personal website or mobile app __for free__ on the click of a button. Like we create facebook profiles. Then why won't they? 

If after doing so, they could post pictures on their website or app and select which ones go to facebook, twitter and which ones are private. And it all happens seamlessly. Will they do it? Will people start navigating off facebook into the personal spaces of their friends to learn more?

Will this then, reduce facebook to a simple discovery platform. This will be ironical, because many of these trends, including technologies like reactjs and graphQL have been created by facebook.

This is all possible right now. I mean the technology to create websites and apps on a click. Just think about it, this website is built from a gatsby template, from data lying in __contentful__. It is built, auto deployed and hosted for free using __netlify__. These are examples of micro services and templates. 

Now think Progressive Web Apps (PWAs).

Maybe ... or all of this could just be a thinking fallacy.

Maybe the world is simply a template with intelligence running inside it. Think DNA.

PS: If you are planning a start up to do the above. You could hire me to be the CTO :)

c166JR8T91o2Cyu6kOuCOyedescriptionTextNo.description: The technology stack which powers sherpafeet.com, a platform for trekking guides in the Indian Himalayas.

internal.content: The technology stack which powers sherpafeet.com, a platform for trekking guides in the Indian Himalayas.

c166JR8T91o2Cyu6kOuCOyeblogTextNode.blog:
[sherpafeet](https://sherpafeet.com) is a platform for trekking guides. Trekking guides is a disorganised industry.
Anyone who has done a couple of treks can claim to be a trek guide. Thats great. But in the process, the native people who depend on this profession for their livelihood were losing out. sherpafeet is a social enterprise which not only helps the native people but is grounded on the core concepts of sustainability.

## Technology which drives sherpafeet
The sherpafeet platform is built on the MERN Stack. That is
- [Mongodb](https://www.mongodb.com/)
- [reactjs](https://reactjs.org)
- [Express](https://expressjs.com)
- [Nodejs](https://nodejs.org)


## Hosting and Devops
The platform is hosted on Amazon Web Services.

## Search Functionality
The search functionality on sherpafeet is powered by [Elastic Search](https://www.elastic.co/)

## APIs
Instead of the traditional REST APIs we use [GraphQL](http://graphql.org/)

![Featured Image of test blog](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/r42cQMeDdIIGwYuw6qay4/81f74976b37358a175fb6a5ec281446d/bg.jpg)

c5ZU6XxdyMwwEkKqIigGYwedescriptionTextNo.description:
Technology is a great enabler and we feel everyone has a right to use the best technology.
If you are a social enterprise, Not for profit or NGO, we can help you with technology.

internal.content:
Technology is a great enabler and we feel everyone has a right to use the best technology.
If you are a social enterprise, Not for profit or NGO, we can help you with technology.

c5ZU6XxdyMwwEkKqIigGYweblogTextNode.blog:
Photo by Chelsea Aaron on Unsplash

Technology is a great enabler and we feel everyone has a right to use the best technology. If you are a social enterprise or NGO, we can help you with technology. ## How we can help Social Enterprises If your social enterprise or NGO, inspires us we can help you in the following ways at no cost. - As a technology consultant. - An online presence with a static website. - An online blog for your Organisation. As we have a pipeline of requests which we are fulfilling, expect about 2-3 months of time before we can fulfill your request. ## Maintenance, support and future proofing. Bug fixes, new features is a critical aspect which many ignore. Over a period of time, this costs more than the actual development efforts. We feel this challenge is best addressed by open sourcing the code. All the code we use to develop software is open source. We strongly believe open source developers and communities are the future of software development. Open sourcing the code is the first step to tap into this eco-system. ## Technology we use We are strongly opinionated on technology. There are some technologies we love and some technologies we avoid. The reason we avoid some technologies is because we feel they may not be dominant in the future. ## Social Causes which resonate with us. Below are a few social causes which we may like more than others. - Education for under privileged children. - Support and care for mental illness. - Support and research for cancer. - Waste Mgmt, sustainability & climate.

c3zDfdcnBqEqKqmMoYcumQIdescriptionTextNo.description: Steps for configuring AWS CODE deploy.

internal.content: Steps for configuring AWS CODE deploy.

c3zDfdcnBqEqKqmMoYcumQIblogTextNode.blog:
Here I describe how we could use AWS Code deploy to transfer your code to an EC2 server for deployment. AWS code deploy can be used for much more, but that is not the topic of this blog.

If you have a single server (and not a cluster) you could do a much simpler deployment by using SSH and shell scripts.

For AWS Code deploy to transfer the code to your production or staging server. You need to do the following

  
## AWS Code Deploy Setup

1. EC2 instance should have an IAM profile which allows it to access S3. 
For a new EC2 instance which has to be launched, follow the steps in this [link](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/getting-started-create-iam-instance-profile.html)
For an existing EC2 instance, run the below command:

```sh
aws ec2 associate-iam-instance-profile --instance-id i-xyzabcdef --iam-instance-profile Name=Myapp-Instance-Profile

aws ec2 describe-iam-instance-profile-associations
```
The above is described in more detail in this [link](https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/new-attach-an-aws-iam-role-to-an-existing-amazon-ec2-instance-by-using-the-aws-cli/)

2. The EC2 instance should have the AWS code deploy agent running, you can get running by doing the following on a unix server. This downloads the code deploy from the ap-south-1 region. 

```sh
wget https://aws-codedeploy-ap-south-1.s3.amazonaws.com/latest/install
chmod +x ./install
sudo ./install auto
Now check status:
sudo service codedeploy-agent status
```

The above steps are further described in this [link]( https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/codedeploy-agent-operations-install-linux.html).

3. An AWS Code deploy APP would need to be created. You will need to create a deployment group within the app. The deployment group will reference the ec2 instance above. This should be straightforward.


4. You would need to create a policy which allows code deploy to access s3.

```sh
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": ["s3:ListAllMyBuckets","s3:PutObject"],
      "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*"
    },
   {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": ["codedeploy:*"],"Resource": "*"
   }
 ]
}
```



  
## Setup on your code structure

On your code structure, you would need to create an appspec.yml file which could contain commands which you need to execute on deployment.

An appspec yaml file is as simple as shown below, this tells AWS code deploy to run the `installCode.sh` shell script for Application Start. Like the `ApplicationStart` tag below, there are other life cycle hooks available.

```sh
version: 0.0
os: linux
files:
  - source: /
    destination: /home/ec2-user/build
hooks:
  ApplicationStart:
    - location: installCode.sh
      timeout: 300
      runas: root
```

A Sample appspec.yml file, can be found in this [link](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/reference-appspec-file.html#appspec-reference-server)

Thats about it, for the setup. To push code to your EC2 instance you would have to run the below commands. [Assuming you have the aws cli and keys installed on your system]

```sh
$ aws deploy push --application-name <application-name> --s3-location s3://<bucket name>/<any build name> --source <directory>

$ aws deploy create-deployment --application-name <application-name> --s3-location bucket=<bucket-name>,key=<any build name>,bundleType=zip,eTag=<tag from deploy command> --deployment-group-name <deployment group name>
```


Hope this was useful. You could write to me at jaikant@gmail.com


In this post we will create a barebone blogging website from scratch using GatsbyJs. *The purpose being to learn a few basic concepts of Gatsbyjs.* Blogs will be in markdown format and will reside in github. ## Step 1: Install Prerequisites - Nodejs & Gatsby If you don’t have Node.js installed, go to [https://nodejs.org/](https://nodejs.org/) and install the recommended version for your operating system. Install the Gatsby CLI as below: ```javascript npm install --global gatsby-cli ``` ## Step 2: Install the barebones gatsby starter kit for this blog. We will do a git clone followed by a npm install of the starter kit. Note[Optional read]: Gatsby provides a `gatsby new` command which does a git clone followed by an npm install. But we will not use that, as we want to checkout branches from the git repository further down the tutorial. ```javascript git clone https://github.com/Jaikant/gatsby-blog-starter npm install ``` The starter kit above is the default starter kit with a few extra plugins to process markdowns and images for our blogs. ## Step 3: Take a peek at the starter kit. ###### TLDR: The gatsby develop command starts the dev server, The page directory in gatsby contains the pages. Now, lets take a look at the gatsby structure. ```sh src ├── pages │ ├── index.jsx ├── templates │ └── ... └── layouts └── index.jsx ``` The `pages` directory is a special one for gatsby. Any `.js` file created here is detected by Gatsby and is converted into a page. The `src/layouts` is another directory which is worth taking a look at now. This directory contains the layout of the page, more specifically the 'header' which will be constant across all pages. The `src/templates` directory is of importance as well, but we will look into it at a later step. The `src/components` directory is a place where we can place our react components. We named it `components`, but it can be named anything. Now, lets learn how to run gatsby in our development environment. In the development environment we will run the below command. Gatsby provides hot reloading in the development environment for both code and styles. ```javascript cd gatsby-blog-starter/ gatsby develop ``` On successful start, you will be able to access the development server at [http://localhost:8000](http://localhost:8000). On opening this link ... ![gatsby-tut-0](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/1wWYasFyZuaAy8Ky88UUyM/3902ea41426681bff36559f989b3d68f/gatsby-tut-0.png) Now, Lets look at the source code for this page. ```javascript cd src/pages/ vi index.js ``` ```jsx import React from 'react' import Link from 'gatsby-link' const IndexPage = () => (

Hi people

Welcome to your new Gatsby site.

Now go build something great.

Go to page 2
) export default IndexPage ``` Thats about it, the index.js contains all the code needed. Now lets take a look at the directory structure: ## Step 4: Lets get our sample blogs. ###### TLDR: Markdown is passed as props to react components Lets pull some sample blogs from github. ```javascript git checkout markdowns ``` Assuming you are in the 'src/pages' directory. If you list the files in the directory. You will be able to see the markdown file(index.md) and an image file within the directory. ```sh . └── src ├── pages ├── index.js └── dayara-bugyal | ├── index.md | │-- dayara.jpg └── gaumukh-tapovan └── hampta-pass └── kuari-pass ``` We will use the image for the blog previews as well as for the cover picture for the blog. Lets take a look inside the index.md. These markdown file will be added to the gatsby data layers and we will pull the content of these files into our react components using graphQL. The content of the markdown will be passed as props to the react components. For now, you could just see the simple structure of the file. ```sh --- title: "Dayara Bugyal Trek" --- ![](dayara.jpg) Dayara Bugyal is perhaps one of the most beautiful alpine meadow in India. The meadow stretches out far and wide. The panoramic view of the Himalayas from here is breathtaking. Situated at an elevation of about 3048 m, this vast meadow is second to none in natural beauty. The trek goes through open stretches and dense forest at different places. In winters the meadows are covered with snow & look extremely beautiful. ... ``` ## Step 5: Lets build a preview of our blog posts Now lets create a blog preview in the first page. We would have to stop gatsby dev server by pressing a `ctrl + C` in the terminal in which it is running. Now in the other terminal, lets checkout the blog-preview branch. ```javascript git checkout blog-preview ``` After checking it out, lets restart the gatsby dev server. (from a different terminal) ```sh gatsby develop ``` We should now see this at [http://localhost:8000](http://localhost:8000) ![gatsby-tut-1](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/2prKxRLYSccsIq2GAUmaqW/ec848b77eee3e31db991e1999dea312e/gatsby-tut-1.png) In this branch, we have modified the `/src/pages/index.js \`. We have included a graphQL query at the bottom of the react component. During the gatsby build/develop/bootstrap process, this query is run and the output is passed as `data` to the react component. The graphQL query in the index.js is as follows: ```jsx export const BlogsQuery = graphql` query blogsQuery { allMarkdownRemark { edges { node { id frontmatter { title } } } } } ` ``` Lets look at the output of this query. GraphQL provides an interface to run queries. Lets open this interface on our browser. [http://localhost:8000/___graphql](http://localhost:8000/___graphql) Cut and paste the query below in the left hand column of graphiQL and click the run icon on top. ```sh { allMarkdownRemark { edges { node { id frontmatter { title } } } } } ``` The output of the query will be something like below. Just observe the node and its fields which come from the markdowns. The `edges` and `node` are central to the gatsby data layer. All data in gatsby is modelled around the node. If interested you can read about that here, but it is not really needed for this tutorial. [https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/node-interface/](https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/node-interface/) ```sh { "data": { "allMarkdownRemark": { "edges": [ { "node": { "id": "/Users/jai/temp/gatsby-blog-starter/src/pages/gaumukh-tapovan/index.md absPath of file >>> MarkdownRemark", "frontmatter": { "title": "Gaumukh Tapovan - Source of the ganges" } } }, ... ``` Now lets look at the index.js we modified. The graphQL result is contained in `data`. We simply map through `data.allMarkdownRemark.edges` and print the title. ```jsx const IndexPage = ({ data }) => (
{ data.allMarkdownRemark.edges.map((post, index) => { return (

{post.node.frontmatter.title}

) }) }
) ``` ## Step 6: Lets add images to the preview. Lets add an image to the blog preview. First lets stop the gatsby dev server. Lets checkout the `blog-preview-images` branch. ```javascript git checkout blog-preview-images ``` Now lets restart the dev server in another terminal, but before lets delete the .cache directory as it will contain some stale query results. ```sh rm -r .cache gatsby develop ``` Our screen looks like this now. We modified the index.js and the graphQL query. We also changed one other thing, if you find out what that is, do let me know :) ![gatsby-tut-2](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/4tT92h39vWQmy2MesMOOEu/b930456f17b636772b9d1d43bf7330ca/gatsby-tut-2.png) ## Step 7: Lets create all the blog pages. Stop the gatsby dev server. ```javascript git checkout blog-posts ``` Restart the gatsby dev server ```sh gatsby develop ``` And ... our pages will look like below, on clicking the blog preview image. ![gatsby-tut-3](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/1K3Jy2KBuQWigIcEoOQuyA/05d66d7c2c4478cf5d96cc74a800abf6/gatsby-tut-3.png) To create the blog pages, we add a template component in `src/templates` We then use the Gatsby onCreateNode and createPages API in the gatsby-node.js file. We essentially run a graphQL query from gatsby-node.js and pass the output of that to the creatPage API to create our pages. We use the onCreateNode, to add a slug to the markdown fields. The slug determines the url of the page. Thats about it! To create a production build, run the following commands and the build will be available in the `public` directory. ```sh gatsby build ``` This website can be deployed on [netlify](https://netlify.com) in just a few clicks and when intergrated with the code in github, it provides a seamless build and deploy. You would just need to push a blog in markdown format to github and within minutes it would be live, automatically :) It should be pretty simple to figure it out. Any questions you can write to me at `jaikant@gmail.com`.

internal.content:
Wordpress is great. But wait ...there is something better.
Imagine a platform, which gives complete independence to your team of writers, photographers, developers, editors!

<p/>
<p/>
Wordpress is great. But wait ...there is something better.

Imagine a platform, which gives complete independence to your team of writers, photographers, developers, editors! 

The photographers upload the media, the writers use the media and write up the articles. The editors review and publish the articles. The developers simultaneously roll out a new version of the platform.

Now this is possible. 

[Contentful](https://contentful.com) + [Netlify](https://www.netlify.com) + [Tech](https://www.gatsbyjs.org) (Gatsby, Hugo etc) 

Using Contently, your writers, photographers and editors semalessly collaborate.

Your development team rolls out new version in the tech of their choice. Netlify brings the two together and publishes the site as soon as anyone makes an update.

This gives you unmatched performance, security and scalability of static sites with no infrastructure costs. Beautiful. It cannot get better. Really. This architecture is also called the [Jamstack](https://jamstack.org/)

This blog is a very simple example of this arhitecture.

Optimising the sizes of your images gives your users a much better user experience. Here I share some useful tips on how to go about doing this. Also links on how facebook and medium have optimised their image loading for a better user experience.

When we are building tech from scratch we go to work on some mundane but important things which may not be core to our product.

Using an existing CMS system or an existing framework or a site generator makes a lot of things easy as they come built in with whats needed and hence we do not have to re-invent the wheel.

But sometimes, when we are building something unique grounds up, we got to reinvent the wheel, but it is much easier now, as the smart folks have already figured it out and it is about understanding whats already figured out.

One of these things is resizing images to make them responsive. 

Optimising the sizes and resolutions of our images gives our users a much better user experience. User experience is a loaded term and I will not get into that here. But rather will outline a few things about resizing images and making them responsive.

There are typically two dominant use cases. The first one is when the image width is dependent on the screen width and the second one is when the image width is fixed, that is it will have the same width across all devices say - 300px on all screen widths.

In both these cases, we will need to resize the images so it is optimised for multiple screen dimensions and __screen resolutions__ (E.g Retina displays).

Typically it suffices to create images with widths close to 

__1. 200px
2. 400px
3. 800px
4. 1600px
5. 2400px__

If the image height is not fixed, then the image is resized maintaining the aspect ratio of the image.

If the image height needs to be a factor of the width, then when the image is resized it is also cropped.

The entire process of resizing the images to the appropriate sizes and cropping can be automated.

I had hacked together such a piece, which created responsive images for me on the cloud. I used AWS Lambda to resize and crop the images. On Lambda imagmagick and sharp were the two options I had. I went with sharp as it was faster for the resizing use case.

For the responsive code, I referred to the gatsby image plugin. The code is open sourced. The [gatsby image plugin](https://github.com/gatsbyjs/gatsby/tree/master/packages/gatsby-plugin-sharp) provides an easy interface to have responsive images on gatsby sites.

The Img tag, instead of `src`, takes either `sizes` or `resolutions` as its props. The sizes is an object with srcset, src and sizes. 
 (..and more):
 
 ```graphql
 "sizes": {
        "srcSet": "/static/rishikund-62f05.jpg 200w,\n/static/rishikund sajdhar-dc2b4.jpg 400w,\n/static/rishikund-381d6.jpg 800w,\n/static/rishikund-14504.jpg 1024w",
        "sizes": "(max-width: 800px) 100vw, 800px",
        "src": "/static/rishikund sajdhar pic-e7e21d0046509e1f847cfef167ba624f-381d6.jpg"
      }
```

The resolutions is an object with srcSet along with the resolutions like 1x, 1.5x etc, src, width (..and more)

```graphql
"resolutions": {
        "srcSet": "/static/rishikund-47df3.jpg 1x,\n/static/rishikund-9f62f.jpg 1.5x,\n/static/rishikund-34191.jpg 2x",
        "src": "/static/rishikund-47df3.jpg",
        "width": 400,
        "height": 266.796875,
        "aspectRatio": 1.499267935578331
      }
```

The gatsby image plugin uses the sharp library to create the image assests needed! It has a lot more going within it, in terms of making the image loading smooth. 

Gatsby itself, uses GraphQL to fetch the images to hydrate the react components. The GraphQL query to fetch a responsive image of a fixed width and height would be like the following:



Here are a few good links which helped me better my understanding of responsive images and image loading.

[Good website to learn about responsive images](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/HTML/Multimedia_and_embedding/Responsive_images)

[Responsive images, a very nice multi part series blog.](https://cloudfour.com/thinks/responsive-images-101-definitions/)

[This is a pretty long read. Use cases for loading images](http://usecases.responsiveimages.org/)

Below are the next steps, once you have resized your images.

[This Facebook article is 💯 They are powering this system through GraphQL 🔥](https://code.facebook.com/posts/991252547593574/the-technology-behind-preview-photos/)

[How medium does progressive image loading](https://jmperezperez.com/medium-image-progressive-loading-placeholder/)

[The blur up technique for loading background images](https://css-tricks.com/the-blur-up-technique-for-loading-background-images/)

In an upcoming blog, I will share how to resize the image using lambda and sharp with the code I used.
Could templates of technology along with micro services cause the next round of disruption? The current set of start ups are templating technology with micro services!

In the current age of virality, there is a lot of noise, but disruptions happen silently and it may be happening while we speak.

I think AI, VR, AR, IOT are enablers. (I intentionally left out blockchain as I feel it is still in early days)

I believe there are a few silent trends which could be big while being beneficial to the masses. 

I give below a mix of human needs and some upcoming tech capabilites nicely mixed up. So you could join the dots yourself :)

1. __Personalisation__: In the age of technology and bots. There is an even greater need for personalisation. There is also a basic human nature to want to stand out from the rest. Services like facebook do not help in this as all are created equal. __Now think of templates. What if everthing technology was a template.__ 

2. __Templating the web__ : Wordpress made popular the concept of themes. Now we have technologies which is destructuring the web, so it can be more easily constructed. For example, ReactJs. ReactJs is a library which allows developers to create reusable templates for websites and apps. Using this library, it is possible to __build websites from data.__ (This particular website is built using GatsbyJs, a static website generator built in react.). __Now think microservices.
__

3. __Microservices or Serverless:__ __This is a template too.__ Not tied by the browser or anything. A template of your business(logic). Computing has become very cheap, thanks to serverless technologies like AWS Lambda. This will reduce costs tremendously and in many cases will make services free. 

4. __AI__: But AI needs data. How to get data? Think microservices. 

5. __Everything is online__: It is an online world now. *But it is aggregated.* They cannot stand out. Think templates for personalisation.

Now think, if it was possible for anyone to create a personal website or mobile app __for free__ on the click of a button. Like we create facebook profiles. Then why won't they? 

If after doing so, they could post pictures on their website or app and select which ones go to facebook, twitter and which ones are private. And it all happens seamlessly. Will they do it? Will people start navigating off facebook into the personal spaces of their friends to learn more?

Will this then, reduce facebook to a simple discovery platform. This will be ironical, because many of these trends, including technologies like reactjs and graphQL have been created by facebook.

This is all possible right now. I mean the technology to create websites and apps on a click. Just think about it, this website is built from a gatsby template, from data lying in __contentful__. It is built, auto deployed and hosted for free using __netlify__. These are examples of micro services and templates. 

Now think Progressive Web Apps (PWAs).

Maybe ... or all of this could just be a thinking fallacy.

Maybe the world is simply a template with intelligence running inside it. Think DNA.

PS: If you are planning a start up to do the above. You could hire me to be the CTO :)
The technology stack which powers sherpafeet.com, a platform for trekking guides in the Indian Himalayas.

[sherpafeet](https://sherpafeet.com) is a platform for trekking guides. Trekking guides is a disorganised industry.
Anyone who has done a couple of treks can claim to be a trek guide. Thats great. But in the process, the native people who depend on this profession for their livelihood were losing out. sherpafeet is a social enterprise which not only helps the native people but is grounded on the core concepts of sustainability.

## Technology which drives sherpafeet
The sherpafeet platform is built on the MERN Stack. That is
- [Mongodb](https://www.mongodb.com/)
- [reactjs](https://reactjs.org)
- [Express](https://expressjs.com)
- [Nodejs](https://nodejs.org)


## Hosting and Devops
The platform is hosted on Amazon Web Services.

## Search Functionality
The search functionality on sherpafeet is powered by [Elastic Search](https://www.elastic.co/)

## APIs
Instead of the traditional REST APIs we use [GraphQL](http://graphql.org/)

Technology is a great enabler and we feel everyone has a right to use the best technology.
If you are a social enterprise, Not for profit or NGO, we can help you with technology.

Photo by Chelsea Aaron on Unsplash

Technology is a great enabler and we feel everyone has a right to use the best technology. If you are a social enterprise or NGO, we can help you with technology. ## How we can help Social Enterprises If your social enterprise or NGO, inspires us we can help you in the following ways at no cost. - As a technology consultant. - An online presence with a static website. - An online blog for your Organisation. As we have a pipeline of requests which we are fulfilling, expect about 2-3 months of time before we can fulfill your request. ## Maintenance, support and future proofing. Bug fixes, new features is a critical aspect which many ignore. Over a period of time, this costs more than the actual development efforts. We feel this challenge is best addressed by open sourcing the code. All the code we use to develop software is open source. We strongly believe open source developers and communities are the future of software development. Open sourcing the code is the first step to tap into this eco-system. ## Technology we use We are strongly opinionated on technology. There are some technologies we love and some technologies we avoid. The reason we avoid some technologies is because we feel they may not be dominant in the future. ## Social Causes which resonate with us. Below are a few social causes which we may like more than others. - Education for under privileged children. - Support and care for mental illness. - Support and research for cancer. - Waste Mgmt, sustainability & climate.
Steps for configuring AWS CODE deploy.

Here I describe how we could use AWS Code deploy to transfer your code to an EC2 server for deployment. AWS code deploy can be used for much more, but that is not the topic of this blog.

If you have a single server (and not a cluster) you could do a much simpler deployment by using SSH and shell scripts.

For AWS Code deploy to transfer the code to your production or staging server. You need to do the following

  
## AWS Code Deploy Setup

1. EC2 instance should have an IAM profile which allows it to access S3. 
For a new EC2 instance which has to be launched, follow the steps in this [link](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/getting-started-create-iam-instance-profile.html)
For an existing EC2 instance, run the below command:

```sh
aws ec2 associate-iam-instance-profile --instance-id i-xyzabcdef --iam-instance-profile Name=Myapp-Instance-Profile

aws ec2 describe-iam-instance-profile-associations
```
The above is described in more detail in this [link](https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/security/new-attach-an-aws-iam-role-to-an-existing-amazon-ec2-instance-by-using-the-aws-cli/)

2. The EC2 instance should have the AWS code deploy agent running, you can get running by doing the following on a unix server. This downloads the code deploy from the ap-south-1 region. 

```sh
wget https://aws-codedeploy-ap-south-1.s3.amazonaws.com/latest/install
chmod +x ./install
sudo ./install auto
Now check status:
sudo service codedeploy-agent status
```

The above steps are further described in this [link]( https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/codedeploy-agent-operations-install-linux.html).

3. An AWS Code deploy APP would need to be created. You will need to create a deployment group within the app. The deployment group will reference the ec2 instance above. This should be straightforward.


4. You would need to create a policy which allows code deploy to access s3.

```sh
{
  "Version": "2012-10-17",
  "Statement": [
    {
      "Effect": "Allow",
      "Action": ["s3:ListAllMyBuckets","s3:PutObject"],
      "Resource": "arn:aws:s3:::*"
    },
   {
     "Effect": "Allow",
     "Action": ["codedeploy:*"],"Resource": "*"
   }
 ]
}
```



  
## Setup on your code structure

On your code structure, you would need to create an appspec.yml file which could contain commands which you need to execute on deployment.

An appspec yaml file is as simple as shown below, this tells AWS code deploy to run the `installCode.sh` shell script for Application Start. Like the `ApplicationStart` tag below, there are other life cycle hooks available.

```sh
version: 0.0
os: linux
files:
  - source: /
    destination: /home/ec2-user/build
hooks:
  ApplicationStart:
    - location: installCode.sh
      timeout: 300
      runas: root
```

A Sample appspec.yml file, can be found in this [link](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/codedeploy/latest/userguide/reference-appspec-file.html#appspec-reference-server)

Thats about it, for the setup. To push code to your EC2 instance you would have to run the below commands. [Assuming you have the aws cli and keys installed on your system]

```sh
$ aws deploy push --application-name <application-name> --s3-location s3://<bucket name>/<any build name> --source <directory>

$ aws deploy create-deployment --application-name <application-name> --s3-location bucket=<bucket-name>,key=<any build name>,bundleType=zip,eTag=<tag from deploy command> --deployment-group-name <deployment group name>
```


Hope this was useful. You could write to me at jaikant@gmail.com
A step by step guide to build a personal blog using gatsbyjs and netlify. Gatsbyjs is a javascript tool which uses react and graphql to generate optimised and performant websites.

In this post we will create a barebone blogging website from scratch using GatsbyJs. *The purpose being to learn a few basic concepts of Gatsbyjs.* Blogs will be in markdown format and will reside in github. ## Step 1: Install Prerequisites - Nodejs & Gatsby If you don’t have Node.js installed, go to [https://nodejs.org/](https://nodejs.org/) and install the recommended version for your operating system. Install the Gatsby CLI as below: ```javascript npm install --global gatsby-cli ``` ## Step 2: Install the barebones gatsby starter kit for this blog. We will do a git clone followed by a npm install of the starter kit. Note[Optional read]: Gatsby provides a `gatsby new` command which does a git clone followed by an npm install. But we will not use that, as we want to checkout branches from the git repository further down the tutorial. ```javascript git clone https://github.com/Jaikant/gatsby-blog-starter npm install ``` The starter kit above is the default starter kit with a few extra plugins to process markdowns and images for our blogs. ## Step 3: Take a peek at the starter kit. ###### TLDR: The gatsby develop command starts the dev server, The page directory in gatsby contains the pages. Now, lets take a look at the gatsby structure. ```sh src ├── pages │ ├── index.jsx ├── templates │ └── ... └── layouts └── index.jsx ``` The `pages` directory is a special one for gatsby. Any `.js` file created here is detected by Gatsby and is converted into a page. The `src/layouts` is another directory which is worth taking a look at now. This directory contains the layout of the page, more specifically the 'header' which will be constant across all pages. The `src/templates` directory is of importance as well, but we will look into it at a later step. The `src/components` directory is a place where we can place our react components. We named it `components`, but it can be named anything. Now, lets learn how to run gatsby in our development environment. In the development environment we will run the below command. Gatsby provides hot reloading in the development environment for both code and styles. ```javascript cd gatsby-blog-starter/ gatsby develop ``` On successful start, you will be able to access the development server at [http://localhost:8000](http://localhost:8000). On opening this link ... ![gatsby-tut-0](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/1wWYasFyZuaAy8Ky88UUyM/3902ea41426681bff36559f989b3d68f/gatsby-tut-0.png) Now, Lets look at the source code for this page. ```javascript cd src/pages/ vi index.js ``` ```jsx import React from 'react' import Link from 'gatsby-link' const IndexPage = () => (

Hi people

Welcome to your new Gatsby site.

Now go build something great.

Go to page 2
) export default IndexPage ``` Thats about it, the index.js contains all the code needed. Now lets take a look at the directory structure: ## Step 4: Lets get our sample blogs. ###### TLDR: Markdown is passed as props to react components Lets pull some sample blogs from github. ```javascript git checkout markdowns ``` Assuming you are in the 'src/pages' directory. If you list the files in the directory. You will be able to see the markdown file(index.md) and an image file within the directory. ```sh . └── src ├── pages ├── index.js └── dayara-bugyal | ├── index.md | │-- dayara.jpg └── gaumukh-tapovan └── hampta-pass └── kuari-pass ``` We will use the image for the blog previews as well as for the cover picture for the blog. Lets take a look inside the index.md. These markdown file will be added to the gatsby data layers and we will pull the content of these files into our react components using graphQL. The content of the markdown will be passed as props to the react components. For now, you could just see the simple structure of the file. ```sh --- title: "Dayara Bugyal Trek" --- ![](dayara.jpg) Dayara Bugyal is perhaps one of the most beautiful alpine meadow in India. The meadow stretches out far and wide. The panoramic view of the Himalayas from here is breathtaking. Situated at an elevation of about 3048 m, this vast meadow is second to none in natural beauty. The trek goes through open stretches and dense forest at different places. In winters the meadows are covered with snow & look extremely beautiful. ... ``` ## Step 5: Lets build a preview of our blog posts Now lets create a blog preview in the first page. We would have to stop gatsby dev server by pressing a `ctrl + C` in the terminal in which it is running. Now in the other terminal, lets checkout the blog-preview branch. ```javascript git checkout blog-preview ``` After checking it out, lets restart the gatsby dev server. (from a different terminal) ```sh gatsby develop ``` We should now see this at [http://localhost:8000](http://localhost:8000) ![gatsby-tut-1](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/2prKxRLYSccsIq2GAUmaqW/ec848b77eee3e31db991e1999dea312e/gatsby-tut-1.png) In this branch, we have modified the `/src/pages/index.js \`. We have included a graphQL query at the bottom of the react component. During the gatsby build/develop/bootstrap process, this query is run and the output is passed as `data` to the react component. The graphQL query in the index.js is as follows: ```jsx export const BlogsQuery = graphql` query blogsQuery { allMarkdownRemark { edges { node { id frontmatter { title } } } } } ` ``` Lets look at the output of this query. GraphQL provides an interface to run queries. Lets open this interface on our browser. [http://localhost:8000/___graphql](http://localhost:8000/___graphql) Cut and paste the query below in the left hand column of graphiQL and click the run icon on top. ```sh { allMarkdownRemark { edges { node { id frontmatter { title } } } } } ``` The output of the query will be something like below. Just observe the node and its fields which come from the markdowns. The `edges` and `node` are central to the gatsby data layer. All data in gatsby is modelled around the node. If interested you can read about that here, but it is not really needed for this tutorial. [https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/node-interface/](https://www.gatsbyjs.org/docs/node-interface/) ```sh { "data": { "allMarkdownRemark": { "edges": [ { "node": { "id": "/Users/jai/temp/gatsby-blog-starter/src/pages/gaumukh-tapovan/index.md absPath of file >>> MarkdownRemark", "frontmatter": { "title": "Gaumukh Tapovan - Source of the ganges" } } }, ... ``` Now lets look at the index.js we modified. The graphQL result is contained in `data`. We simply map through `data.allMarkdownRemark.edges` and print the title. ```jsx const IndexPage = ({ data }) => (
{ data.allMarkdownRemark.edges.map((post, index) => { return (

{post.node.frontmatter.title}

) }) }
) ``` ## Step 6: Lets add images to the preview. Lets add an image to the blog preview. First lets stop the gatsby dev server. Lets checkout the `blog-preview-images` branch. ```javascript git checkout blog-preview-images ``` Now lets restart the dev server in another terminal, but before lets delete the .cache directory as it will contain some stale query results. ```sh rm -r .cache gatsby develop ``` Our screen looks like this now. We modified the index.js and the graphQL query. We also changed one other thing, if you find out what that is, do let me know :) ![gatsby-tut-2](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/4tT92h39vWQmy2MesMOOEu/b930456f17b636772b9d1d43bf7330ca/gatsby-tut-2.png) ## Step 7: Lets create all the blog pages. Stop the gatsby dev server. ```javascript git checkout blog-posts ``` Restart the gatsby dev server ```sh gatsby develop ``` And ... our pages will look like below, on clicking the blog preview image. ![gatsby-tut-3](//images.contentful.com/ojam5vx77jn8/1K3Jy2KBuQWigIcEoOQuyA/05d66d7c2c4478cf5d96cc74a800abf6/gatsby-tut-3.png) To create the blog pages, we add a template component in `src/templates` We then use the Gatsby onCreateNode and createPages API in the gatsby-node.js file. We essentially run a graphQL query from gatsby-node.js and pass the output of that to the creatPage API to create our pages. We use the onCreateNode, to add a slug to the markdown fields. The slug determines the url of the page. Thats about it! To create a production build, run the following commands and the build will be available in the `public` directory. ```sh gatsby build ``` This website can be deployed on [netlify](https://netlify.com) in just a few clicks and when intergrated with the code in github, it provides a seamless build and deploy. You would just need to push a blog in markdown format to github and within minutes it would be live, automatically :) It should be pretty simple to figure it out. Any questions you can write to me at `jaikant@gmail.com`.
